The static scanner detected patterns in documentation text that do not represent actual security risks. No file access, network calls, or command execution capabilities exist in this skill.

content.user_title: Convert Plans to Executable Task Beads
content.value_statement: Planning complex projects for AI agents is difficult because traditional task formats lack dependency awareness and self-contained context. This skill provides proven prompts to transform any markdown plan into detailed beads with explicit dependencies so agent swarms can execute work correctly without confusion.
actual_capabilities: Convert any markdown project plan into granular, self-contained tasks called beads
Add explicit dependency relationships between tasks to prevent execution errors
Polish and refine bead descriptions through iterative AI review cycles
Generate comprehensive unit and e2e test coverage recommendations
Coordinate multi-agent work using bead IDs with Agent Mail conventions
Run cross-model reviews using Claude, Codex, and Gemini CLI
limitations: Requires the external bd and bv CLI tools to be installed and functional
Cannot execute code or create files directly on the filesystem
Does not provide built-in integration with project management tools like Jira or Linear
Bead quality depends on the quality of the input markdown plan

use_cases.title: Coordinate AI Development Teams
use_cases.description: Break down complex feature specs into granular, executable tasks that multiple AI agents can work on in parallel without conflicts.

use_cases.title: Structure Solo AI Pair Programming
use_cases.description: Convert architectural plans into systematic work units that keep Claude or Codex focused and prevent context switching.

use_cases.title: Review AI-Generated Code Quality
use_cases.description: Use the polishing workflow to verify that AI-generated implementation plans maintain feature completeness and technical rigor.

prompt_templates.title: Plan to Beads
prompt_templates.scenario: Convert a markdown plan into tasks
prompt_templates.prompt: Read ALL of my_project_plan.md and create a comprehensive set of beads with tasks, subtasks, and dependency structure overlaid. Include detailed comments with background, reasoning, and justifications so the whole thing is self-contained. Use the bd tool.

prompt_templates.title: Polish Beads
prompt_templates.prompt: Review each bead carefully. Is it optimal? Could we improve anything? Revise the beads to ensure no features are lost and comprehensive unit tests and e2e test scripts are included. Use the bd tool.

prompt_templates.title: Add Test Coverage
prompt_templates.prompt: Do we have full unit test coverage without mocks? What about complete e2e integration test scripts with detailed logging? If not, create a comprehensive set of beads for test coverage with tasks, subtasks, and dependency structure.

prompt_templates.title: Cross-Model Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review these beads using bv to check for cycles and dependencies. Analyze with --robot-insights for bottlenecks. Provide a fresh perspective on any issues that previous review rounds may have missed.

output_examples.input: Convert my authentication redesign plan into beads
output: BD-100: Design OAuth2 provider architecture with 3 subtasks, blocked by BD-050
BD-101: Implement token encryption storage with 2 subtasks, depends on BD-100
BD-102: Create user session management with 4 subtasks, parallel with BD-101
BD-103: Build login flow UI components with 2 subtasks, depends on BD-101
BD-104: Add unit tests for auth module, depends on BD-100, BD-101, BD-102
BD-105: Add e2e tests for OAuth flow, depends on BD-104

output_examples.input: Polish my existing beads for a React migration project
output: Review cycle 1 complete: Added 12 missing edge case considerations
Review cycle 2 complete: Added integration test beads for all API endpoints
Review cycle 3 complete: Fixed 3 dependency cycles found by bv --robot-insights
Quality gate passed: All 45 beads are self-contained and testable

best_practices: Run at least 6-9 polishing rounds before implementation to catch issues in plan space
Use fresh Claude Code sessions when polishing flatlines to get new perspectives
Always verify with bv --robot-insights that no dependency cycles exist before execution
Include Agent Mail thread IDs in all communication to track work by bead
anti_patterns: Skipping polishing rounds and going straight to implementation
Oversimplifying beads and losing important features from the original plan
Not including explicit test coverage beads for every feature bead
Creating beads that require consulting the original markdown plan
Missing dependency links between blocking and blocked tasks

faq.question: What tools do I need to install first?
faq.answer: You need the bd (Beads CLI) and bv (Beads Viewer) tools installed. These are separate from this skill and must be set up in your environment.

faq.question: How many polishing rounds are recommended?
faq.answer: Aim for 6-9 rounds of polishing. Continue until changes become minimal. Use fresh sessions when progress flatlines.

faq.question: Can I use this with other AI models beyond Claude?
faq.answer: Yes. The methodology supports Codex with GPT 5.2 for final review and Gemini CLI for alternative perspectives on bead quality.

faq.question: Is my project data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: This skill only contains prompts. No data is sent anywhere. All data handling depends on the bd and bv tools you use.

faq.question: Why do my beads need dependencies?
faq.answer: Dependencies prevent agents from working on blocked tasks. The bv tool uses these to recommend what is ready to work on.

faq.question: How is this different from Jira or Linear?
faq.answer: Beads are designed specifically for AI agents. They are self-contained, verbose, and include reasoning that helps AI models maintain context across sessions.
